questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An administrator is configuring a new WLAN for a wireless network that has these requirements:

• Dual-band clients that connect to the WLAN must be directed to the 5-GHz spectrum.
• Wireless clients on this WLAN must be able to apply VLAN settings on the returned RADIUS attributes.

Which two actions meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
The requirements state that dual-band clients connecting to the WLAN should be directed to the 5-GHz spectrum, and wireless clients on this WLAN must be able to apply VLAN settings on the returned RADIUS attributes. Let's analyze the options:

A. Enable the Client Band Select option.

This option encourages dual-band clients to connect to the 5-GHz spectrum, so it meets the first requirement.
B. Enable the Coverage Hole Detection option.

Coverage Hole Detection is not directly related to the specified requirements.
C. Enable the Allow AAA Override option.

AAA Override allows RADIUS attributes to override WLAN settings. This is relevant to the second requirement.
D. Set the MFP Client Protection option to Required.

MFP (Management Frame Protection) is not directly related to the specified requirements.
E. Enable the Aironet IE option.

The Aironet IE (Information Element) is not directly related to the specified requirements.
Therefore, the correct options are:

A. Enable the Client Band Select option.
C. Enable the Allow AAA Override option.

Selected Answer: AC
A & C are correct

choices.A: Enable the Client Band Select option.
choices.B: Enable the Coverage Hole Detection option.
choices.C: Enable the Allow AAA Override option.
choices.D: Set the MFP Client Protection option to Required.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Access to this GUI is usually secured using HTTPS, ensuring encryption of data exchanged between the administrator's web browser and the WLC.

choices.A: using the AP GUI via an in-band SSH connection
choices.C: using the CLI via a virtual interface with SSH
choices.D: using the WLC GUI via HTTPS
choices.B: using the CLI via an out-of-band connection

questions.question_text: How does a network administrator securely manage an AP in lightweight mode?

choices.B: uses Cisco-proprietary First Hop Redundancy Protocol
choices.A: allows two or more routers to act as a default gateway
choices.C: uses a destination IP address 224.0.0.102 for router-to-router communication

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

A. allows two or more routers to act as a default gateway

VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol) is a standard protocol that allows multiple routers to work together in order to provide high availability for a network's default gateway. The routers share an IP address and a virtual MAC address, and one router is elected as the active router while the others act as backups. If the active router fails, one of the backup routers takes over to maintain seamless network connectivity.

Option A accurately describes the purpose of VRRP, making it the correct choice. VRRP is commonly used to ensure continuous operation of the default gateway, which is crucial for maintaining connectivity in a network.

questions.question_text: Which type of protocol is VRRP?

choices.B: Excessive collisions are causing dropped frames.
choices.A: A bad checksum is causing Ethernet frames to drop.
choices.D: The interface output queue cannot process the Ethernet frames.
choices.C: A large number of broadcast packets are resulting in a port reset.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The switch cat9k-acc-1 connects users to the campus LAN. Printing services are inaccessible through the network. Which interface issue is causing the connectivity problems?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It should be C. A large number of broadcast packets are resulting in a port reset.

comments.content:
CRC errors are usually related to layer 1 problems (cable, duplex, speed mismatch)

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/internetworking/troubleshooting/guide/tr1904.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
If a broadcast storm occurred, it would be strange if 'ignored' 'no buffer' counter did not go up.

comments.content: Who knows what Cisco thinks when they make these scenarios. :)

discussion.content: another weird one, maybe a red herring, but i wonder... why is the gigether interface operating at 1Mb/s? and why does the output queue only have a max of 1 packet that it can hold?

comments.content: excessive broadcast traffic can congest the network and disrupt normal operations, potentially impacting service availability

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: A
Given these details, the most likely cause of connectivity problems, based on the information provided, is:

A. A bad checksum is causing Ethernet frames to drop.

CRC and framing errors suggest an issue with the physical layer that could be causing frames to be dropped due to a bad checksum. This would directly impact the reliability of data transmission, including services like printing.

This was the AI answer 
The interface issue causing the connectivity problems on the switch cat9k-acc-1, which is hindering access to printing services through the network, is most likely option D: "The interface output queue cannot process the Ethernet frames." This conclusion is drawn from the fact that there were 1 underrun, 1 collision, and 1 interface reset observed in the output of the "show interfaces gigabitethernet 1/0/1" command. These indicators suggest that the interface is struggling to handle the volume of Ethernet frames efficiently, leading to dropped frames and potential connectivity issues for services like printing.

Additionally, excessive collisions (option B) and a large number of broadcast packets (option C) could also potentially cause connectivity problems but are not directly supported by the provided information. The presence of underruns and interface resets points more towards an issue with the interface's output queue processing capability.
